newsitem.title: ITALY: FOCUS-Italy's Stet sets sights on AT&T link.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS-Italy's Stet sets sights on AT&T link.

text.p: Italian state telecommunications giant Stet is aiming to forge an alliance with U.S. telecoms giant AT&T Corp by the end of the year, Stet managing director Tomaso Tommasi di Vignano said on Wednesday.
Tommasi, talking to reporters at a meeting of Italian employers here, said Stet was working intensively on reaching an accord with AT&T.
He gave no details, but asked when such an accord with the U.S. group might happen, he said: "The objective is to have an accord on an international alliance by the year end."
Stet has been seeking a big international partner for months to turn it into a major player on the increasingly competitive world telecoms stage.
It has a limited cooperation deal with U.S. computer giant IBM and linked up earlier this year with AT&T to bid for the privatisation of Brazil's cellular phones.
Italian media have speculated the original AT&T partnership might lead to a bigger agreement although up until now both companies have offered no comment.

The Italian group, which has a strong presence in south America, is looking to expand further and is bidding with Spain's Endesa for the privatisation of the country's Retevision as well as taking a 29 percent stake in Serbia Telekom.
The Rome government is keen to get a major international partnership in place before it privatises Stet, a move which is now expected to take place next October after many delays.
Tommasi said he expected a decree covering the Stet sell-off to be presented to the cabinet in the next few days and said the placement was due to take place in October.
"That's the course that's been stated. That's what we're working for...I am confident and I am also willing to do all that it requires," he added.
Stet's sale has been repeatedly postponed mostly because of the government's difficulty in pushing legislation through parliament to set up a watchdog to regulate the telecoms sector.
After months of haggling, the authority bill is now ready for a final reading in the lower house of parliament after being approved by the upper house of parliament (Senate) last month.

As part of the privatisation plan, Stet is also being merged with state-controlled telephone operator Telecom Italia . The fusion is due to become operational in mid-July with the resulting company taking the Telecom Italia name.
